heading: rants and raves
subheading: date: monday, september 20, 1999 4:37 pm from: dwayne a neckles (dneckl01@utopia.poly.edu) to: newsfeedback@wired.com subject: the myth of the pocket protector this is in reference to (“the myth of the pocketprotector,” 20.sep.99). i would like to commend you on the article you wrote concerning the image of techies. it was very nice seeing that because […]
author: wired blogs
text: date: monday, september 20, 1999 4:37 pm from: dwayne a neckles (dneckl01@utopia.poly.edu)to: newsfeedback@wired.comsubject: the myth of the pocket protectorthis is in reference to ("the myth of the pocketprotector," 20.sep.99). i would like to commend you on the article you wrote concerning the image of techies. it was very nice seeing that because i am a black student whose major is computer science at a polytechnic university in brooklyn, [where only] 11 percent of the students are black ... because "its not cool". unfortunately, those people don't really know what technology has to offer them.i think if hollywood [and] television ads depicted computers techinicians and engineers in a more positive way then maybe there would be more computer scientists out there. anyway, i think that it is possible to market computer technology in a way that would attract younger adults, and even teens.
